- I'm here training
with Georges St-Pierre.
Probably the greatest fighter of all time,

and also one of the
nicest guys of all time.
- Not the nicest guy, not today.
(Georges laughs)

Not today Lex, you came on
the wrong thing, my friend.
- He's breathing hard.
(Georges screams)
(light smacks)
Any advice (indistinct)?
(Georges laughs)
- Try not to die.
(Georges laughs)
- If he dies, he dies.
- If he dies, he dies.
(both grunting)
- Ooh!
- Any advice?
- Well, it's actually pretty good.
Standing position, I think,
sometime you reach a little bit too much.
So if you reach out to me,
it's easy for me to take a good position,
or reach out to me,
I can probably like climb back on you.
So what I was suggesting, don't reach,

I get closer with your feet
before you seek contact with me.
Don't go here.
Go closer to establish here.
- Yeah.
(Lex grunting)
- Yes.
(Lex grunting)
(thuds)
(Georges chuckles)

- So how is it different
if you're doing MMA?
- Well, there's a lot of difference
because in grappling, you set up,

for example, you take
down from him fighting,
in MMA, if there's different styles,

I like to be using proactive
and reactive take down.

Very often, I use one of my
longest weapon as a decoy

to get in your leg, use my
jab to create a distraction,
then I can get in.
Other guys, for example,
like Khabib are more like chain wrestle.

They shoot sometime, but
they're very good at using,

for example, the fence as
like pushing you to the fence,

and then from there they're
using their resting from there.

So I'm more of a dynamic
idea, I like to explode.
So that's one of my strength,
which Khabib is very good,
for example, at very good technically,

and he's very strong in
isometric strength, I heard.

So he's very good with
this style of wrestling.
- Do you think you can take Khabib down?

- I think I could, yeah.
- Yeah.

- I think he could take
me down as well, but.
- So how do I defend against this?
- So there's many ways.

First, you need to be aware
of the distance control.
That's one of the thing I was the best at.
To master the distance control,
you need to master the footwork,

to be always in balance
and ready to explode.
A lot of guy, they don't know
how to manage distance control,

also because they don't
have good footwork.

They cross their leg, they
go all over the place.
So when you move, it's important to when,
if I go left, I push up with my right.
(indistinct)
If I go right, I push up with my left,
I go back, I push with my lead,
I go forward, I push with my back.
This is the basic.

Thereafter, you can
use different illusion.
So if I'm here, I look

and I'm more of a trap
to you that if I'm here,
but I mean I'm at the same distance.

So one of my favorite,
which setup I take down,
a single or double, I use my jab,
which is one of my longest weapon.
Of course, my legs are longer,

but I like the jab to
take the distraction.
So if I'm here, you see me coming.
So I use a distraction.
I'm here, and like a cold brew,

like a snake will launch
itself on its spray.
I'm using my body to boom.

So you have a false
feeling of security now
because you think I can't touch you,
but because of my leg, boom.
And my...
- Oh, you're shifting your weight.
- Yes.
- And now you can explode off that.

- And my jab start outside
of your field of vision.
So I'm not doing this,

I'm doing purposely, I'm
putting it down and I'm here,
and I'm attracting your attention here
because I'm moving my hand.
Boom!

Once I tag you once or twice,
now I have a perfect setup,

because now in fighting you
have a short term memory.

You always remember
what hurts you the last.
And if it's my job, then I can very,

I plant a seed in your
line, then I can go hop
and get in easier.
- When you finish hop, you drop.
- There is many ways.
The best highest per second move
is the elbow deep double leg.

So when I get in, I try to
look across when I step across.
So I get in, I go elbow deep.

The reason why I don't
only go with my legs

is because if you're
stronger and bigger than me

and you sprawl from there,
I can have a hard time.
But if I go elbow deep,
because of the leverage, you can't sprawl.

Once I'm in, I look
across and I drive across

(thuds)
to put you down.
Sometime you'll fight a guy,
like for example, Bisping was very strong,
and I couldn't drive across.

So when that happened, if
you can't drive across,
you turn the corner.
(thuds)

That's, they get they
open up on the other side.
Would you like to try?

- Sure.
- Yeah.
- So from here.

(quick smacks)
- Yes.
Go with your elbow deep here,
and now you're gonna drive across.
Yes.
Step across with you, yes.
If you do it again, good jab.
Set it up, jab.
Now go ahead, go for it.
Yes, yes, exactly.

And if I give you
resistance, once you get in,

I'm strong and I'm
strong, spreading my leg,
if you turn the corner.
So jab set it up a few times.
Yeah.
I'm sprawling.
Yes!
Very nice.

You feel the difference?
- Yeah.

- So if he's too strong,
you go on the other side,

don't force corner, don't
waste your energy for nothing.
You try to be as kind as you can,
as possibly you could be.
- What about on the ground?

What's the difference in
jiu-jitsu for you and MMA?
- Well, there's a lot of difference.

I believe in jiu-jitsu,
especially in the guard,
you can't stay in mid range.
- Yeah.
- I don't want to cover like this,
like if I'm in a standing position,
I want to cover like this.
My head is on the ground,

my muscle and of my
abdominal are contracted.
- Mm hmm.
- So it's possible for you to damage here,

but because I'm contracted,
it's less likely.

So I want to focus all
the protection on my head.

- You okay with this?
- Yeah, it's okay.
It's okay.
But I want to be here.

So I there's a gap where
I can see you here.

- Yeah.
- If I'm here,

it's not as efficient 'cause
you can go on the side,
and it's easy for you to grab my wrist,
put it down, and hit.
Yeah.

If I'm here, it's harder
for you to control my arm.

If you want to grab it,
it's hard for you to grab.
So that's the first thing.
Another thing, if your hands are here,
I want to take away your hand on me.
I want to pull you to me.
I wanna control your head and your arm.
And from there, there's a many option.
I like to take that arm

because it control your
elevation and you can't hit me.

It's either I'm very close
to you or I'm very far.
- Can you try to get up?
- I'm very far, yeah.
If I can't get up, no problem.
I'm using my leg to push you away

or I can use the tip of my
feet to create distance.

So you need to be aware that I
can kick you in the head too.
So it's either very close or very far.
- What about the top?

If you...
- On top, yeah.

So if I'm on top, the
best position for me to be
ultimately is not even mount,
is to have your back let you to the floor
from this position.

'Cause now you cannot
hit me, I can't hit you,

and I can either knock
you out or submit you.
This is the worst.
Mount is the second best
because I'm having a lot of control mount
and also with my knees under your armpit,
the worst would be in your guard.
So it's not as bad as
if you would be in a jiu-jitsu competition
because I have the gravity on my side.

But if I'm here, I need
to respect three rules.

I never want you to put
my hands on the floor,
go submission, all kinds of things.
You can very easily wrap my arm
and wrap my head closer distance,
and now it's a pain for me.
So no way on the floor.

I don't want you to have
your head higher than my head

because if your head
is higher than my head,
you have (indistinct).
It's very hard for me to control

and do anything to you if my
head is lower than your head.
And another thing, the third thing is

I don't want to let you
take an angle of me.

So if you take an angle,
towards would you get that me,
you see, you need to take an angle.
- Yeah.

- So if I take away that
angle, I kill your offense.
- Mm hmm.

- So my hands always on
you, never on the floor.

- Are you hitting and you
trying to hit a little bit?
- Yeah, I can hit them the same time.
If you try to raise your head up,
I don't accept it in my head high.

If you try to take an angle,
I put you back in line.
So if I respect these three rules

as I'm respecting this
rule, I can cause damage
even if I'm in the guard.

But my goal is always
eventually to pass the guard,
get to a more dominant position.
- I love it.

- It's in a nutshell,
that's what it's about.

- Well, thank you Georges.
- Nah man, hey.

- You guys got a chance
to train with Elon?
To watch him train,

takes steps on his martial arts
journey, what do you think?
- I think he's very strong,
much stronger than the average man.
He's got a lot of heart, he's very tough.
- So I've always found that,
by far and away the most important thing,
two people get into a clash,
skill level trumps everything else

in terms of what's
gonna turn me out there.
- Skill beats hard.
- Skill beats it.

That's not to say other
things aren't relevant,
but skill is more relevant.

From what I understand,
his proposed opponent

is almost two years of
training experience.
That's a big advantage.
So it would be an uphill battle.

I will say however, though
that he deeply impressed

both Georges and myself
with his overall ability

to grasp the subject very
quickly, extremely intelligent,
and see what is the crux of the problem,
identifies what would need to be done.
But I also believe that

he's probably one of the busiest
human beings on the planet.

- That said, these guys
do martial arts training,
martial arts is pretty...

- I think, ultimately the
deepest both of these guys,
amazing 21st century society.
And those have a lot of work to do.
And I think there are two people
who have put themselves in a position

where they can create
greater benefits for humanity
than almost anyone else in the planet.
And so there's a sense in which
I wish they would focus more on that

than fighting each other.
(Lex chuckles)
- Alright, so one more round.
This is for everything.
It's a submission.

- This is for the greatest
